items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
New board policy 2710 concerning the responsibility of trustees to avoid and disclose conflicts of interest was presented for first reading at the May 5 and October 6, 2014, meetings. The language of the legally required policy is derived directly from applicable provisions of the California Government Code and California Code of Regulations. An overview of conflict of interest laws prepared by district legal counsel John Shupe of Lynch and Shupe is attached for reference.
	 
The policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on January 17, 2014. 
	 
References:
Government Code Sections 1090 et seq., 1126, and 87100 et seq.
Title 2 Sections 18730 et seq.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, Chancellor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has nine pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment.  The District’s Educational Technology Services staff determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers.  Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).
items.item_text: Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project will repair the steel column, concrete footings, beams, and electrical wiring to the solar panel canopy system in Parking Lot #2 that was damaged by a passenger bus that was preparing to wait for K-12 students attending an event at Foothill College. ATI Architects & Engineers prepared the bid specifications for the work.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on September 5 and September 12, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on October 9, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office. Three (3) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:
BID RESULTS
Contractor
Base Bid 
Proposal Amount
R. C. Benson & Sons, Inc.
$ 98,000
Rodan Builders Inc.
$105,000
Coulter Construction, Inc.
$119,960
	 
The apparent low bidder, R. C.  Benson & Sons, Inc. has confirmed that its bid price of $98.000 is true and accurate for the work as specified. Benson has successfully performed work for the District including completion of the swing space renovations and remodel for the Foothill College Library Renovation project. Benson is currently completing the Curb Cut and Fence project at De Anza College.
	 
The construction estimate for the repair is $100,000 - $114,000. The bid price of $98,000 is well within the estimate and will be paid for by Plant Services Capital Project Funding.  Meanwhile, the District is seeking reimbursement of its expenses via an open insurance claim.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, x6166
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen - x6150, Jennifer Mahato - x6178, Gina Bailey - x6165
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document 1699 – Repair to Damaged Solar Panel Canopy System in Parking Lot #2 at Foothill College in the amount of $98,000 to R. C. Benson & Sons, Inc.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project is a rebid of Bid 1674 with revised scope of work.  The work solves the issues concerning the aging boiler equipment and the hot water distribution to the showers.  The Project includes: purchasing and installing three (3) new high-efficiency condensing boilers; replacing piping and valves to provide heat for the surrounding PE buildings, dive well, swimming pool; adding two (2) new pumps and variable frequency drives for the building hot water loop and two (2) new pumps for the pool hot water loops. The work includes reconnecting the new boilers into the existing cogen systems and connecting the PE complex to the campus Building Management System (BMS). The project provides efficient hot water delivery to the showers with the purchase and installation of one (1) new high-efficiency condensing boiler, one (1) new circulation pump and modifications to the piping. For better equipment servicing, the project includes the relocation of the existing pulsar chlorination units, the CO2 bulk tank and associated pool chemicals and pumps to an above-grade location. 
The Alternates include: (#1) replacing the pool and building hot water heat exchangers and associated piping/components; (#2) adding a second condensing boiler for the domestic hot water loop to provide redundancy and minimize overburdening of the equipment; and (#3) adding gauges and controls to better observe and maintain operations of the equipment.
	 
The bid legally advertised to contractors on September 4 and September 11, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on September 18, 2014 and a total of eight (8) contractors attended the walk. Bids were publicly opened and read on October 8, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office. Five (5) contractors submitted bids.
	 
BID RESULTS
Contractor
Base Bid Proposal Amount (incl. $20K in allowances)
Alt #1
Pool & Dive Well Heat Exchanger
Alt #2 Install Second Water Heater
Alt #3 Add Transmitters & Connect to EMS
Grand Total w/Base Bid plus Alternates 1-3
Environmental Systems Inc. of Northern California
$803,400

$893,995 
					 
Lyles Mechanical Co.
$849,000

R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors
$922,700

Rodan Builders, Inc.
$1,045,000
$47,000
$67,000
$28,000
$1,187,000 
					 
	 
The apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder was Environmental Systems Inc. of Northern California (ESI). Purchasing Services staff has confirmed that ESI has successfully completed projects for other public agencies such as City of San Jose and Palo Alto High School Haymarket Boiler. 
	 
The base bid proposal price of $803,400 submitted by ESI exceeds the engineer’s estimate of $770,000; however, upon review it is noted that the estimate provided by the engineer was only for a portion of work and did not include the relocation of the chemicals, the additional work associated with more efficient heating to the PE buildings and showers, and the three (3) alternates. After reviewing the additional costs for these omissions, the bids are reasonable in comparison to the estimate.  The total bid amount including Alternates 1 through 3 of $893,995 is within the overall project budget of $1,086,700. 
	 
This project shall be partially funded by year 1 funding under Proposition 39, California Clean Energy Jobs Act (2012), and Plant Services Capital Projects Funds.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Steve Kitchen, Donna Jones Dulin, Tom Armstrong, Jennifer Mahato, Annette Perez 
Is backup provided?
No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District expects to make several Measure C and Non-Measure C funded purchases of Steelcase furniture. Because the estimated cost of the furniture may exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $84,100, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”. The competitively bid Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) contract with Steelcase is available and it includes the items that may be required by the District. The FCCC contract was awarded under a competitive solicitation following the provisions of California’s Public Contract Code. The Foundation acted in the capacity of a California Community College District and infused piggybackable language to allow for any of California’s community colleges to utilize the Agreement.
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the FCCC contract for the same goods and services. The FCCC contract establish discounts for furniture inclusive of specification development services, space planning services, installation drawings, shipping and delivery costs, a 15-year parts and labor warranty, and installation services. On larger purchases, the district negotiates lower pricing than what is offered on the contract. 
	 
In addition, Steelcase makes a donation of one percent for all purchases to the California Community Colleges Scholarship Endowment.  All donations that result from the District’s purchases will be allocated to the District’s account and the resulting scholarships will go to the Foothill-De Anza students.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Steve Kitchen, Roseanne Sciacchitano, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue purchase orders for furniture and related services in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and the Foundation for California Community Colleges Contract # 13-015.
items.item_text: Authorize the use of Foundation for California Community Colleges contract to purchase furniture and related services from Steelcase pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 21. Authorize the use of Foundation for California Community Colleges contract to purchase furniture and related services from Steelcase pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
A bond-funded project was planned to construct a new building for Educational Technology Services (ETS) to house a data center and other ETS functions.  Technological advances that made a data center unnecessary and the decision to use the District Office Building for ETS offices have required re-planning of projects to provide for all of the programmatic needs of ETS.
	 
Re-directing Measure E and Measure C funds originally assigned to the data center building can provide for ETS’s needs and result in cost savings that can be directed to the New District Offices project.  Bond list revisions appearing on this Board of Trustees meeting agenda include budget transfers that will fund projects to meet those programmatic needs.  The Measure E bond list revision appears as item #24 on the agenda; the Measure C bond list revision appears as item #26.
	 
The attached Power Point presentation describes ETS’ change of program and more fully explains the complexity of the required budget transfers. A presentation from staff will be given to the Board of Trustees in the open meeting that will clarify the details of the Power Point presentation and answer any questions the Trustees may have.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Change Order #9
Vendor:  Alten Construction
Agreement Date:  October 17, 2013
Campus:  Foothill College
Project Number:  420
Project Name:  District Office Building Renovation
Amount:  $227,435.00
For:
	 
Changes made primarily to accommodate Educational Technology Services (ETS) use of the building, as directed by the architect’s redesign document, Bulletin #16.  The most notable cost is for modifications to electrical and telecommunication systems, reflecting ETS’s intense demand on those systems.  The contractor has proceeded with this work under negotiated change directives authorized by the Board of Trustees at its October 6, 2014 meeting.  
	 
This change order also includes minor changes requested by the District for added plumbing valves and ceiling repair, as well as fire line modifications required by the fire department.
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders equal 20.2% of the base contract value excluding the time extension cost.   The funding for this change requires approval of a budget transfer proposed in a separate agenda item at this Board of Trustees meeting.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations, extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Director, Bond Program Management, Foothill College
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval
items.item_text: Alten Construction - Change Order #9 - District Office Building Renovation - $227,435.00
items.item_text_raw: A) Alten Construction - Change Order #9 - District Office Building Renovation - $227,435.00

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Information was provided to the Board of Trustees on December 7, 2009, and January 19, 2010, concerning the use of a Lease-Leaseback construction procurement process for Measure C projects.  The information included a discussion of the legal aspects of the process as well as the likely risks and benefits associated with construction using the authority provided under the Education Code section 81335. On August 31, 2010, a default judgment was issued by the Santa Clara County Superior Court which confirmed the validity of the use of this procurement process.  Since that time the Board has approved the use of Lease-Leaseback procurement for several projects: the Media and Learning Center, the Physical Sciences & Engineering Center, the District Data Center and the Advanced Technology Center.
	 
The procurement process for this project will be consistent with the process used for previously-approved projects, and it will include the same key decision/Board approval steps.  The Board will be requested to review and approve key decisions and actions in the procurement process over a period of time.  Target dates for key actions associated with the project are as follows: 
February, 2015 - Approval of the Lease-Leaseback contractor based upon a Request for Qualifications and Request for Proposals process.
February, 2015 -  Award of a pre-construction services agreement for the Lease- Leaseback contractor.
April, 2015 - Approval of a Site Lease and a Facilities Lease with the Lease- Leaseback contractor including a guaranteed maximum price for building renovation based on DSA-approved plans and Specifications. 
Mid-April, 2015 – Construction commences on the L-7 building.
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen , Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
 Tom Armstrong, Director, Bond Program Management, De Anza College
Donna Jones-Dulin, Associate Vice President, Finance & Educational Resources, De Anza College
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: The Executive Director of Facilities and Operations recommends that the Board approve the initiation of a construction procurement process under the Lease-Leaseback provision of Education Code section 81335 for the L-7 project subject to the subsequent Board approvals as noted.
items.item_text: Lease-Leaseback Construction Procurement Process for the De Anza College L-7 renovation project

Background and Analysis:
	 
This revision is required to implement Bond list changes that are needed to adjust and prioritize approved project scopes and funding at Foothill, District/Central Services and De Anza College.  
	 
De Anza Budget Transfer #46 includes the following actions:
Transfer $233.74 project savings from Project 214, Corporation Yard to Project 248, Campus Drive to add funds to the project. Project 214 is financially complete.
Transfer $168,610.28 from Project 201, A-8 to Project 248, Campus Drive to add funds to the project. Project 201 is cancelled. 
Transfer $150,000 from Project 403, CS Data Center “C” to Project 202, L-7 to compensate the Budget for Programming Phase costs. Please reference District Central Services BT#17.
Transfer $60,652.71 of Interest Earned in Quarter 3 Fiscal Year 2013/2014 to Project 248, Campus Drive to add funds to the project.
Note that current budget for Project 248, Campus Drive will have additional funding source of $84,288.21 due to PG&E Rebates (Checks 46, 49-50 Series 1 and Checks 28-29 Series 2) not shown here.
Foothill Budget Transfer #48 includes the following actions:

District/Central Services Budget Transfer #17 includes the following actions:

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The project includes relocation of existing PG&E gas meter from Lot 1A to Lot 1, including all required gas distribution piping installation. Alternate 1 includes an additional gas connection from D100 to D140, however, due to budgetary reasons the Director of Bond Construction is recommending not to award this alternate.  Alternate #2 includes re-routing of existing gas line from Building 6500 to Building 5100, the scope includes demo of hardscape, trenching, installation of gas line and restoration of sidewalk.
	 
Sandis Engineers Surveyors Planners prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
Bid #1705-135 was legally advertised to contractors August 29, 2014, and September 4, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on September 11, 2014, and a total of eight (8) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on September 30, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office.  Three (3) contractors submitted a bid and the bid results are summarized below:
	 
General Contractors
Base Bid Proposal Amount Includes $40,000 (Allowances 1-4)
Alternate 1
Alternate 2
Total Base Bid Proposal Amount Plus Alternates 1 & 2 
Hoi’s Construction Inc.
$420,000
$43,700
$82,000
$545,700
ARB, Inc. 
$520,622.80
$135,430.51
$94,622.64
$750,975.95
Lewis & Tibbits, Inc.
$538,000
$135,600
$132,000
$805,600
	 
	 
A notice of Intent to Award was sent to all bidders on October 3, 2014 and on October 7, 2014, Purchasing Services staff received a bid protest letter from the second apparent low bidder, ARB, Inc. (ARB).  The letter alleges that Hoi’s Construction Inc. (Hoi’s Construction) is not a responsible bidder. Purchasing Services consulted with District's legal counsel and found Hoi’s Construction’s bid to be legally compliant.  
	 
Purchasing Services staff confirmed that Hoi’s Construction Inc., completed Project #113, Press Box at Foothill College.  In addition, they have also successfully completed projects for other public agencies such as San Francisco Unified School District, Charity Cultural Services Center in San Francisco, and City College of San Francisco.  
	 
Hoi’s Construction Inc. and its listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
	 
Hoi’s Construction's base bid proposal price, plus Alternate #2 equals $502,000 and is over the construction estimate of $500,000, however, it is within the overall project budget of $600,000.  This project is funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Steve Kitchen, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Deny the bid protest submitted by ARB, Inc., and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid #1705-135, Gas Meter Relocation in the amount of $502,000 to Hoiâs Construction Inc.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1705-135, Gas Meter Relocation at Foothill College (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 27. Award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1705-135, Gas Meter Relocation at Foothill College (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On September 10, 2012, the Board of Trustees authorized award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement to C. W. Driver (CWD) as the Lease-Leaseback contractor for the Education Center (Project). The Preconstruction Services Agreement requires CWD to solicit competitive bids to develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for each of three Project construction phases.  On July 1, 2013 the Board of Trustees approved execution of the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease for the Project, which included a GMP for only the Site Demolition Phase of the project.  CWD has completed that phase of work for the amount of the GMP.  
	 
This Amendment modifies the Facilities Lease to include a GMP for an Early Site Work Phase of the Project in the amount of $2,634,288.  This phase includes: improvements to Innovation Way in accordance with the Memorandum of Agreement with the City of Sunnyvale; sanitary sewer service; domestic water service; reclaimed water service; fire water service; natural gas service; and underground work in preparation for electric and telecommunication work to be installed by service providers.  This work falls under the jurisdiction of the City of Sunnyvale and the respective utility providers, so it does not require approval by the Division of the State Architect (DSA).  The GMP includes some work to provide utility connections for the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) for which the District will be reimbursed by that agency under a Memorandum of Agreement between the District and VA.
	 
During construction of this Early Site Work Phase a GMP for the following Building and Site Construction Phase will be developed by CWD.  Upon approval of building plans by DSA, a final Amendment to the Facilities Lease will be brought to the Board of Trustees that will include the GMP for that phase and the final cost for all phases. The construction budget for all Project phases is $25,200,000.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, x6166
Additional contact names:
Steve Kitchen, x6150; Art Heinrich, x6295
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, to execute Amendment #1 to the Facilities Lease with C. W. Driver, and to accept a GMP in the amount of $2,634,288 for the Early Site Work Phase of the Project.
